text_001.title: At the Supermarket
text_001.content: Jeg går i supermarkedet hver onsdag. Jeg køber mælk, brød og frugt. Jeg kan også lide ost og smør.
text_001.translation: I go to the supermarket every Wednesday. I buy milk, bread and fruit. I also like cheese and butter.

text_002.title: Greetings
text_002.content: Hej! Hvordan har du det? Jeg har det godt, tak. Hvad hedder du?
text_002.translation: Hello! How are you? I am fine, thank you. What is your name?

text_003.title: My Family
text_003.content: Jeg har en mor, en far og to søstre. Min mor hedder Anna, og min far hedder Peter. Mine søstre hedder Line og Sofie.
text_003.translation: I have a mother, a father and two sisters. My mother is called Anna and my father is called Peter. My sisters are called Line and Sofie.

text_004.title: At School
text_004.content: Jeg går i skole hver dag. Min lærer er venlig. Jeg lærer dansk, matematik og engelsk. Jeg kan godt lide at læse bøger.
text_004.translation: I go to school every day. My teacher is friendly. I learn Danish, math and English. I like reading books.

text_005.title: The Weather
text_005.content: I dag er vejret godt. Det er solrigt og varmt. I morgen bliver det koldt, og det vil regne.
text_005.translation: Today the weather is good. It is sunny and warm. Tomorrow it will be cold and it will rain.

text_006.title: My Hobbies
text_006.content: I min fritid spiller jeg fodbold. Jeg elsker også at cykle og svømme. Om aftenen læser jeg bøger eller ser fjernsyn.
text_006.translation: In my free time I play football. I also love cycling and swimming. In the evening I read books or watch TV.

text_007.title: In the City
text_007.content: København er Danmarks hovedstad. Der er mange smukke bygninger og parker. Mange mennesker cykler rundt i byen.
text_007.translation: Copenhagen is Denmark's capital. There are many beautiful buildings and parks. Many people cycle around the city.

text_008.title: At the Restaurant
text_008.content: Jeg vil gerne bestille mad. Kan jeg få en pizza og en cola? Hvad koster det?
text_008.translation: I would like to order food. Can I have a pizza and a coke? How much does it cost?

text_009.title: Daily Routine
text_009.content: Jeg står op klokken syv om morgenen. Jeg spiser morgenmad og børster mine tænder. Derefter tager jeg i skole.
text_009.translation: I get up at seven in the morning. I eat breakfast and brush my teeth. Then I go to school.

text_010.title: Transportation
text_010.content: Jeg tager bussen til arbejde. Min kone kører bil. Vores børn cykler til skole, fordi det er sundt.
text_010.translation: I take the bus to work. My wife drives a car. Our children cycle to school because it is healthy.

text_011.title: Job Interview
text_011.content: Sara er til jobsamtale i en stor virksomhed. Hun er nervøs, men godt forberedt. Intervieweren spørger om hendes erfaring og styrker. Sara forklarer, at hun er meget organiseret og arbejder godt i teams. Hun nævner også, at hun kan tale tre sprog: dansk, engelsk og spansk. Efter samtalen føler Sara sig optimistisk om sine chancer.
text_011.translation: Sara is at a job interview at a large company. She is nervous but well prepared. The interviewer asks about her experience and strengths. Sara explains that she is very organized and works well in teams. She also mentions that she can speak three languages: Danish, English and Spanish. After the interview, Sara feels optimistic about her chances.

text_012.title: At the Market
text_012.content: Hver lørdag går Morten på det lokale marked for at købe friske grøntsager. I dag køber han tomater, agurker og løg til en salat. Sælgeren fortæller ham, at tomaterne er økologiske og kommer direkte fra en lokal gård. Morten beslutter også at købe nogle æbler, selvom de er lidt dyrere end i supermarkedet. Han kan lide at støtte lokale producenter.
text_012.translation: Every Saturday, Morten goes to the local market to buy fresh vegetables. Today he buys tomatoes, cucumbers and onions for a salad. The seller tells him that the tomatoes are organic and come directly from a local farm. Morten also decides to buy some apples, even though they are a bit more expensive than in the supermarket. He likes to support local producers.

text_013.title: Doctor's Appointment
text_013.content: Lise har ondt i halsen og skal til læge. Lægen undersøger hende og konkluderer, at hun har en halsbetændelse. Han udskriver antibiotika og råder hende til at hvile sig i tre dage. Lise spørger, om hun må gå på arbejde, men lægen siger, at det er bedre at blive hjemme for ikke at smitte kollegerne. Lise lover at følge lægens råd.
text_013.translation: Lise has a sore throat and needs to see a doctor. The doctor examines her and concludes that she has a throat infection. He prescribes antibiotics and advises her to rest for three days. Lise asks if she can go to work, but the doctor says it's better to stay home so as not to infect colleagues. Lise promises to follow the doctor's advice.

text_014.title: Danish Hygge
text_014.content: Hygge er en vigtig del af dansk kultur. Det handler om at skabe en hyggelig og tryg atmosfære. Om vinteren tænder danskerne mange lys og stearinlys. De drikker varm kakao eller te og nyder tid med familie og venner. Hygge kan også være at læse en god bog under et varmt tæppe. Mange udlændinge synes, at hygge er en af de bedste ting ved Danmark.
text_014.translation: Hygge is an important part of Danish culture. It's about creating a cozy and safe atmosphere. In winter, Danes light many lights and candles. They drink hot cocoa or tea and enjoy time with family and friends. Hygge can also be reading a good book under a warm blanket. Many foreigners think that hygge is one of the best things about Denmark.

text_015.title: Environmental Concerns
text_015.content: Danmark arbejder hårdt for at beskytte miljøet. Regeringen har sat ambitiøse mål for at reducere CO2-udledningen. Mange danskere cykler i stedet for at køre bil, hvilket er godt for både miljøet og sundheden. Vindmøller producerer en stor del af landets elektricitet. Derudover sorterer de fleste borgere deres affald for at fremme genbrug. Disse tiltag viser, at Danmark tager klimaforandringer alvorligt.
text_015.translation: Denmark works hard to protect the environment. The government has set ambitious goals to reduce CO2 emissions. Many Danes cycle instead of driving, which is good for both the environment and health. Wind turbines produce a large part of the country's electricity. In addition, most citizens sort their waste to promote recycling. These measures show that Denmark takes climate change seriously.

text_016.title: Planning a Trip
text_016.content: Emma og hendes kæreste planlægger en ferie til Italien. De vil gerne besøge Rom, Firenze og Venedig. Emma foretrækker at bo på små hoteller, mens hendes kæreste synes, at Airbnb er billigere og mere autentisk. De bliver enige om at prøve begge dele. Emma begynder at researche seværdigheder og restauranter. Hun glæder sig især til at se Colosseum og smage ægte italiensk pizza.
text_016.translation: Emma and her boyfriend are planning a vacation to Italy. They want to visit Rome, Florence and Venice. Emma prefers to stay at small hotels, while her boyfriend thinks Airbnb is cheaper and more authentic. They agree to try both. Emma starts researching attractions and restaurants. She's especially looking forward to seeing the Colosseum and tasting real Italian pizza.

text_017.title: Technology and Life
text_017.content: Smartphones har ændret vores hverdag markant. Vi bruger dem til kommunikation, navigation, shopping og underholdning. Mange unge mennesker kan ikke forestille sig et liv uden deres telefon. Dog advarer eksperter om, at for meget skærmtid kan være skadeligt for mental sundhed. Det er vigtigt at finde en balance mellem det digitale og det virkelige liv. Nogle familier har indført 'telefonfri zoner' ved middagsbordet.
text_017.translation: Smartphones have changed our daily lives significantly. We use them for communication, navigation, shopping and entertainment. Many young people cannot imagine life without their phone. However, experts warn that too much screen time can be harmful to mental health. It's important to find a balance between digital and real life. Some families have introduced 'phone-free zones' at the dinner table.

text_018.title: University Studies
text_018.content: Michael studerer økonomi på Københavns Universitet. Han er i sit andet år og finder studiet både udfordrende og interessant. Selvom forelæsningerne er krævende, nyder han at diskutere økonomiske teorier med sine medstuderende. Michael overvejer at tage et semester i udlandet, måske i Singapore eller USA. Han tror, at international erfaring vil være værdifuld for hans fremtidige karriere.
text_018.translation: Michael studies economics at the University of Copenhagen. He's in his second year and finds the program both challenging and interesting. Although the lectures are demanding, he enjoys discussing economic theories with his fellow students. Michael is considering spending a semester abroad, perhaps in Singapore or the USA. He believes that international experience will be valuable for his future career.

text_019.title: Danish Christmas Traditions
text_019.content: Jul er en meget speciel tid i Danmark. Familierne samles den 24. december for at fejre juleaften. Traditionen er at spise and eller flæskesteg med brune kartofler og rødkål. Efter middagen danser man rundt om juletræet og synger julesalmer. Børnene venter spændt på julemanden, som bringer gaverne. Mange danskere hygger sig også med en julekalender hver dag i december.
text_019.translation: Christmas is a very special time in Denmark. Families gather on December 24th to celebrate Christmas Eve. The tradition is to eat duck or roast pork with caramelized potatoes and red cabbage. After dinner, people dance around the Christmas tree and sing carols. Children wait excitedly for Santa Claus, who brings the presents. Many Danes also enjoy an advent calendar every day in December.

text_020.title: Finding an Apartment
text_020.content: At finde en lejlighed i København er en stor udfordring. Priserne er høje, og der er stor efterspørgsel. Thomas har søgt i flere måneder uden held. Han har været til mange fremvisninger, men der er altid mange andre interesserede. En ejendomsmægler råder ham til at være hurtig med at beslutte sig. Thomas overvejer nu at flytte til Frederiksberg eller Valby, hvor huslejen er lidt lavere.
text_020.translation: Finding an apartment in Copenhagen is a big challenge. Prices are high and there is great demand. Thomas has been searching for several months without success. He has been to many viewings, but there are always many other interested parties. A real estate agent advises him to be quick to decide. Thomas is now considering moving to Frederiksberg or Valby, where the rent is slightly lower.

text_021.title: Work-Life Balance
text_021.content: Danskere værdsætter work-life balance meget højt. De fleste virksomheder har fleksible arbejdstider, og det er normalt at forlade kontoret klokken 16 eller 17. Familietid betragtes som meget vigtig, og forældre bruger ofte fritiden sammen med deres børn. Desuden har danske arbejdere fem til seks ugers ferie om året. Denne balance bidrager til danskernes generelt høje livskvalitet og tilfredshed.
text_021.translation: Danes value work-life balance very highly. Most companies have flexible working hours, and it's normal to leave the office at 4 or 5 pm. Family time is considered very important, and parents often spend leisure time with their children. In addition, Danish workers have five to six weeks of vacation per year. This balance contributes to Danes' generally high quality of life and satisfaction.

text_022.title: Climate Change Debate
text_022.content: Klimaforandringer er et varmt debatemne i Danmark. Politikere diskuterer, hvordan landet kan blive CO2-neutralt inden 2050. Nogle foreslår højere grønne afgifter, mens andre mener, at teknologisk innovation er løsningen. Unge aktivister demonstrerer jævnligt for hurtigere handling. Forskere advarer om, at havstigningen kan true de danske kyster. Der er bred enighed om, at der skal handles nu, men uenighed om metoderne.
text_022.translation: Climate change is a hot topic of debate in Denmark. Politicians discuss how the country can become CO2-neutral by 2050. Some propose higher green taxes, while others believe that technological innovation is the solution. Young activists regularly demonstrate for faster action. Scientists warn that sea level rise could threaten Danish coasts. There is broad agreement that action must be taken now, but disagreement about the methods.

text_023.title: The Public Library
text_023.content: Det lokale bibliotek er mere end bare et sted at låne bøger. Det fungerer som et kulturelt center for hele samfundet. Her kan man deltage i foredrag, workshops og bogklubber. Biblioteket tilbyder også gratis internetadgang og hjælp til jobsøgning. Børn kan komme til eventyr-timer, hvor bibliotekarerne læser højt. Mange ældre bruger biblioteket som et socialt mødested. Det er et eksempel på, hvordan offentlige institutioner kan binde lokalsamfundet sammen.
text_023.translation: The local library is more than just a place to borrow books. It functions as a cultural center for the entire community. Here you can participate in lectures, workshops and book clubs. The library also offers free internet access and help with job searching. Children can come to story hours where librarians read aloud. Many elderly people use the library as a social meeting place. It's an example of how public institutions can bring the local community together.

text_024.title: Danish Cuisine Evolution
text_024.content: Dansk madkultur har ændret sig dramatisk i de seneste årtier. Traditionelt bestod den danske kost hovedsageligt af kød, kartofler og sovs. I dag eksperimenterer danskerne mere med internationale retter og sundere ingredienser. Nye nordiske køkken har gjort Danmark verdensberømt for gastronomisk innovation. Restauranter som Noma har vundet internationale priser. Samtidig er der fornyet interesse for traditionelle retter som smørrebrød og frikadeller, men med moderne twist.
text_024.translation: Danish food culture has changed dramatically in recent decades. Traditionally, the Danish diet consisted mainly of meat, potatoes and gravy. Today, Danes experiment more with international dishes and healthier ingredients. New Nordic cuisine has made Denmark world-famous for gastronomic innovation. Restaurants like Noma have won international awards. At the same time, there is renewed interest in traditional dishes like smørrebrød and frikadeller, but with a modern twist.

text_025.title: The Cycling Infrastructure
text_025.content: Københavns cykelkultur er verdensberømt. Byen har investeret massivt i cykelstier og cykelbro'er for at gøre det sikkert og bekvemt at cykle. Næsten halvdelen af alle københavnere cykler til arbejde eller studie dagligt, selv om vinteren. Cykelstier har forkørselsret mange steder, og der er separate trafiksignaler for cyklister. Andre byer rundt om i verden studerer København som et eksempel på bæredygtig bytransport.
text_025.translation: Copenhagen's cycling culture is world famous. The city has invested massively in bike lanes and bicycle bridges to make cycling safe and convenient. Almost half of all Copenhageners cycle to work or study daily, even in winter. Bike lanes have right of way in many places, and there are separate traffic signals for cyclists. Other cities around the world study Copenhagen as an example of sustainable urban transport.

text_026.title: Social Welfare System
text_026.content: Det danske velfærdssystem er et af de mest omfattende i verden. Staten tilbyder gratis sundhedspleje og uddannelse for alle borgere. Studerende modtager endda SU, en månedlig støtte mens de studerer. Systemet finansieres gennem høje skatter, men de fleste danskere accepterer dette, fordi de ser fordelene. Velfærdsstaten sikrer også arbejdsløshedsunderstøttelse og pensioner. Dog står systemet overfor udfordringer på grund af en aldrende befolkning.
text_026.translation: The Danish welfare system is one of the most comprehensive in the world. The state offers free healthcare and education for all citizens. Students even receive SU, a monthly grant while studying. The system is financed through high taxes, but most Danes accept this because they see the benefits. The welfare state also ensures unemployment benefits and pensions. However, the system faces challenges due to an aging population.

text_027.title: Hans Christian Andersen
text_027.content: Hans Christian Andersen er Danmarks mest berømte forfatter. Han blev født i Odense i 1805 og skrev over 150 eventyr, som er oversat til mere end 100 sprog. Hans mest kendte historier inkluderer 'Den lille havfrue', 'Den grimme ælling' og 'Snedronningen'. Selvom han skrev for børn, indeholder hans eventyr ofte dybe filosofiske budskaber. I dag fejres hans fødselsdag, den 2. april, som International Børnebogenes Dag. Andersens eventyr læses stadig af millioner af børn verden over.
text_027.translation: Hans Christian Andersen is Denmark's most famous author. He was born in Odense in 1805 and wrote over 150 fairy tales, which have been translated into more than 100 languages. His most famous stories include 'The Little Mermaid', 'The Ugly Duckling' and 'The Snow Queen'. Although he wrote for children, his fairy tales often contain deep philosophical messages. Today, his birthday, April 2nd, is celebrated as International Children's Book Day. Andersen's fairy tales are still read by millions of children worldwide.

text_028.title: Danish Democracy
text_028.content: Danmark er et parlamentarisk demokrati med en konstitutionel monark. Dronningen har primært ceremonielle opgaver, mens den egentlige magt ligger hos Folketinget og regeringen. Der afholdes valg mindst hvert fjerde år, og valgdeltagelsen er generelt høj, ofte over 80%. Danskere er stolte af deres demokratiske traditioner og ytringsfrihed. Politiske debatter er livlige, men generelt præget af respekt og kompromissøgning. Tilliden til demokratiske institutioner er blandt de højeste i verden.
text_028.translation: Denmark is a parliamentary democracy with a constitutional monarch. The Queen has primarily ceremonial duties, while the real power lies with the Parliament and government. Elections are held at least every four years, and voter turnout is generally high, often over 80%. Danes are proud of their democratic traditions and freedom of speech. Political debates are lively but generally characterized by respect and compromise-seeking. Trust in democratic institutions is among the highest in the world.

text_029.title: Learning Danish Language
text_029.content: Mange udlændinge finder dansk svært at lære. Udtalen er særlig udfordrende, da mange bogstaver ikke udtales, som man ville forvente. For eksempel siger danskerne 'rødgrød med fløde', som er næsten umuligt for ikke-danskere at udtale korrekt. Grammatikken er dog relativt simpel sammenlignet med mange andre sprog. Danskundervisning tilbydes gratis til indvandrere gennem sprogskoler. Selvom mange danskere taler godt engelsk, sætter de pris på, når udlændinge forsøger at tale dansk.
text_029.translation: Many foreigners find Danish difficult to learn. The pronunciation is particularly challenging, as many letters are not pronounced as one would expect. For example, Danes say 'rødgrød med fløde', which is almost impossible for non-Danes to pronounce correctly. However, the grammar is relatively simple compared to many other languages. Danish language teaching is offered free to immigrants through language schools. Although many Danes speak good English, they appreciate when foreigners try to speak Danish.

text_030.title: Working Remotely
text_030.content: Efter COVID-19 pandemien er fjernarbejde blevet mere almindeligt i Danmark. Mange virksomheder tilbyder nu hybride ordninger, hvor medarbejdere kan arbejde hjemmefra nogle dage om ugen. Dette giver større fleksibilitet og sparer pendlingstid. Dog savner nogle den sociale kontakt med kollegerne. Forskere undersøger, hvordan fjernarbejde påvirker produktivitet og trivsel. Mange forudser, at fremtidens arbejdsplads vil være en blanding af kontorarbejde og hjemmearbejde.
text_030.translation: After the COVID-19 pandemic, remote work has become more common in Denmark. Many companies now offer hybrid arrangements where employees can work from home some days a week. This provides greater flexibility and saves commuting time. However, some miss the social contact with colleagues. Researchers are investigating how remote work affects productivity and well-being. Many predict that the workplace of the future will be a mix of office work and home work.
